docs.lead_paragraph: Trent Lott is all the things that most Republican senators want in a leader. He is a strong partisan. But his manner is smooth, almost unctuous, not occasionally scary like Speaker Newt Gingrich's rhetoric.

headline.main: Road for the Senate's Leader Is Expected to Be Tortuous

docs.abstract: Trent Lott faces no opposition to re-election as majority leader on Dec 3, but it is unclear whether he will succeed as leader of Senate; 105th Congress poses special problems that may not be easily managed by someone with his experience; problem has as much to do with changing nature of Senate as it does with Lott, who was House leader and ally of Speaker Newt Gingrich before coming to Senate in 1989; after retirements and 1996 elections, Senate is distinctly more conservative body, changed more than increase from 53 to 55 Republicans would suggest; with retirements of senators who worked across party lines, Senate has become polarized along an even more important axis than ideology: willingness to work with opponents to reach compromise (M)
docs.snippet: Trent Lott is all the things that most Republican senators want in a leader.    He is a strong partisan. But his manner is smooth, almost unctuous, not occasionally scary like Speaker Newt Gingrich's rhetoric.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Nov. 25 front-page article ''Reduced H.M.O. Fees Cause Concern About Patient Care'' misses three points. First, health maintenance organizations have saved corporate America 40 percent versus the cost of traditional health insurance. Second, capitation -- the H.M.O. practice of paying doctors a fixed sum to cover office care for each enrolled patient -- represents the equivalent of a salary and does not have to reduce the quality of care any more than putting employees on a salary reduces corporate productivity.

headline.main: H.M.O. System Needn't Reduce Quality of Care

docs.abstract: Letter from Kenneth S Abramowitz on quality of HMO's (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Harry and Louise Were Right, Sort Of'' (Week in Review, Nov. 24) details the march to managed care with one omission: the 41 million uninsured. The growth of health maintenance organizations has failed to slow the increase in the number of working Americans without health insurance. Omitting the uninsured from a discussion of health care is like discussing Moby-Dick without mentioning the whale. The 1995 Census Bureau statistic of 41 million uninsured Americans does not even include the 20 million who had health insurance for only part of a year. Thus, the totally uninsured plus the partly uninsured equals 26.8 percent of our population: one-fourth of a nation with no or inadequate health care.

headline.kicker: H.M.O. System Needn't Reduce Quality of Care

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr James S Bernstein claims growth of HMO's has failed to slow increase in number of working Americans without health insurance (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, in a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in Texas, a 17-year-old boy was weathering withdrawal at its worst. His body shuddered with convulsions. He hurled tables and chairs around the hospital. Had he been hooked on heroin? Cocaine? Jim Beam? Joe Camel?
docs.abstract: Smattering of psychologists and therapists say Internet addiction is as real as compulsive gambling, drug abuse and binge eating; psychiatric hospital affiliated with Harvard University has opened computer addiction clinic, and there is Internet addiction support group at University of Maryland; quiz; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TRAMMELL CROW spent four decades becoming the nation's leading real estate developer. But in the late 1980's, everything he had achieved was imperiled by perhaps the worst real estate crash of modern times. It seemed like desperation when he turned to his third son, Harlan, to confront the crisis. Harlan, at age 37, had put up some big buildings in Dallas, even some good ones, but he was still growing out of his reputation as a rich kid who had flunked out of his first college.

headline.main: More Than a Chip Off the Building Block

docs.abstract: Trammell Crow's family is apparently wealthier than ever after a remarkable comeback from near ruin during real estate downturn of late 1980's and early '90's; family's holdings, centered in Crow Family Holdings and directed by Trammell's son Harlan, now reach well beyond ownership and development of real estate into management of properties, including offices, warehouses, apartments and especially hotels; Harlan Crow has also formed investment alliances with the likes of Prudential Insurance and Investcorp; intends to further reduce family's real estate holdings from 60 percent to less than 50 percent of its total wealth; he and his father comment; photos; graphs (L)
